questions.question: Based on this image, which of the following statements are true? (Choose three.)
answers: A. Attributes from two tables populate a table with the same name as a ServiceNow CMDB table.
B. This operation is more than likely a part of a step on a pattern set to Application Pattern Type.
C. If a value is unmatched, it is still merged into the Target Table.
D. For this operation to run, there must be some data in the process.executablePath variable.
E. This is a horizontal pattern of type "infrastructure."

comments.content: E seems more correct than A
ABD is correct considering that the table being merged to is the Web Server table
ABD might actually be correct considering that the table being merged to is the Web Server table

questions.question: Based on the following images, which choice best describes what occurs if Discovery sets the name attribute of a discovered Windows Server CI to 'Windows1' and then Altiris discovery runs detecting 'Windows2' for the name attribute on the same CI?
answers: A. The name of the CI stays 'Windows1'.
B. The name of the CI changes to 'Windows2'.
C. The name of the CI does not populate with either discovery.
D. The CI is not discovered because Discovery is not listed in either image.

comments.content: Lowest (aka highest) priority takes priority, therefore A.

The answer would be "B" based on the higher priority being "ServiceNow." Once the source from the higher priority updates the field it checks the "cmdb_datasource_last_update" table. If the fields been updated the lower priority source is skipped. 

Resource: https://support.servicenow.com/kb?id=kb_article_view&sysparm_article=KB0756709 (Updated Jan 18 2024)
replies: Sorry this wouldn't allow me to correct this. Please disregard the answer is A

comments.content:
Correct answer: A. The name of the CI stays ‘Windows1’.
Reasoning: If multiple data sources are authorized to update the same table in the CMDB based on reconciliation definition, then a lower order data source has higher priority than a higher order data source.
The answer is A due to the order on the Data Source Precedents.
The answer is A because have de order 100
the rules run in the order from lowest to highest.
The answer is "A", no question about it. Why do they have marked "B" as Correct answer ??
I agree the answer should be A, this is based on the ranking of 100  for ServiceNow(higher  than 300 for Altrium)

questions.question: When installing a MID Server on a Windows platform, which right must be associated when creating a Service Account?

comments.content:
1. You can allow read-only in a AD domain without making the account Domain Admin

2. MID has to have log on as a service rights in order to run the MID services on the Windows server.

The provided service account credentials must meet the following requirements in addition to being a valid account.
The user cannot be a local system or an administrator level account (local admin, domain admin, etc.)
The service account provided has the log on as service right, which is required for an account to be used as the log on user for a service.
Know this one from setting up multiple MID servers

Username of the service account that will be used to run the MID Server service. For information on creating service accounts, see Create a Windows service account with "Log on as Service" [KB0867669].

questions.question: Which of the below choices are needed for Quick Discovery? (Choose two.)
In order to use Debug from the Pattern Designer, you must have what?

comments.content: You have to connect to an actual CI in order to debug it. B is correct
You need admin access. C is correct.

It has to be B, bear in mind that a CI has a reasonable number of attributes that a pattern will identify during the discovery process. No Discoverable CI, no point using a pattern, no reason to debug!
Also, pd_admin is NOT the same as the admin role.
replies: I did the SAM Exam, and in the exam they called "sam_admin" as "admin" only, maybe its the case here.

comments.content: B is correct. On page 266 of the Discovery Fundamentals Guide Book it says: "Note: Debug Mode is used to test pattern steps and verify variable values against a CI prior to running discovery".

https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/utah-it-operations-management/page/product/service-mapping/task/t_ActivateDebugMode.html

'Before starting this procedure, verify that the Debug mode is not activated. If the Debug mode is activated, the debug button appears with a green dot: .

Role required: pd_admin

Basic knowledge of programming is desirable.'

questions.question:
A discovery runs against a Windows Server returning the following attribute values for the first time: name = WindowsSN1 serial_number = 12321
A subsequent discovery runs against a different Windows Server returning the following attribute values: name = WindowsSN2 serial_number = 12321
With only base system CI Identifiers configured, which of the following is true?
answers: A. A Windows Server CI is created, then updated with WindowsSN2 as the name.
B. Two Windows Sewer CIs are created, with WindowsSN1 AND WindowsSN2 for names.
C. Two Windows Server CIs are created, without serial_number values.
D. A Windows Server CI is created, then updated with WindowsSN1 as the name.

comments.content: the question says "subsequent discovery is run against a different windows server" this implies that there is a second windows server to consider. In this case, the answer has to be B.
A = serial number match as unique
I believe A is the correct answer

the OOB IRE rule has a higher priority for the serial number (derived from the Hardware Class),  IRE will stop with the first matching condition that delivery a unique identification, therefore it would consider the serialnumber as significant. Thus I opt for A
I would say the answer is A, it would only NOT update the name if a less authoritative  data source was used.
looks to be A as unique serial
A as the serial number unique.
NOT sure why 2 new data needs to be created

From: https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/washingtondc-it-operations-management/page/product/discovery/concept/nmap-credential-less-discovery.html

questions.question:
A network device has both an SSH port and an SNMP port open. Discovery tries the SSH probe first and it fails. This triggers the SNMP probe, which succeeds. Discovery uses SNMP first for subsequent discoveries on that device.
What discovery functionality allows the above to happen?

comments.content:
What IP Service Affinity Does (per the documentation):

	“The IP service affinity functionality stores a mapping between an IP address, port, and the application service class that Discovery identified on that port.”

So:
	•	It remembers what application (e.g., Apache, Oracle, Tomcat) was found running on a specific IP/port combo.
	•	This helps ServiceNow optimize future discoveries of application services, not infrastructure.
A system property called glide.discovery.ip_service_affinity allows Discovery to remember the last port of the IP address that was discovered. This property is set to false by default.
Credential affinity has nothing to do with choosing the order of ports/services to probe.
I believe it is an IP Service Affinity, so I would say D

questions.question: Which of the below choices are horizontal pattern types? (Choose two.)

comments.content:
A pattern is a sequence of commands whose purpose it is to detect attributes of a CI and its outbound connections. Service Mapping and Discovery share a set of preconfigured patterns that cover most of the commonly used devices and applications. Patterns can be of the infrastructure or application type. Infrastructure patterns are used only by Discovery for creating lists of devices. Application patterns serve both Service Mapping and Discovery, which use the same application patterns for their purposes. For example, Discovery runs the horizontal discovery with the Apache Web Server pattern to find and list all Apache Web Servers in your organization. Service Mapping runs the top-down discovery using the same pattern to discover a specific Apache Web Server and place it on an application service map.

https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/vancouver-it-operations-management/page/product/service-mapping/concept/c_MappingPatternsCustomization.html

questions.question: What does the MID Server need to collect vCenter events?
answers: B. MID SNMP Trap Listener extension

questions.question:
A Discovery Schedule contains a /24 subnet IP Range and a Shazzam batch size of 5000.
How many times will a Shazzam probe be launched during discovery?

comments.content:
A. 1

For example, a schedule is created to scan 100,000 IP addresses, with 10 MID Servers assigned to do the work. Each MID Server is assigned to scan 10,000 IP addresses. If the Shazzam batch size is set to 5,000 IP addresses per probe, the schedule runs two Shazzam probes per MID Server (10,000 IP addresses/5,000 per batch). These probes are run in sequence and not concurrently.
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/washingtondc-it-operations-management/page/product/discovery/task/t_CreateADiscoverySchedule.html
A /24 subnet contains 253 usable IPs. And if the Shazzam batch size is configured as 5000. Only one Shazam probe needs to be created to complete the scan.

questions.question: Which method is used by Discovery to determine if a Host IP is active or alive?

comments.content: I think Discovery no longer pings devices, so I think the (most) correct answer here is A

I believe SNOW dumped ping awhile ago. While it is possible to have a CI that has all listening ports closed, it is highly unlikely to the point of near-impossibility (because any device active on a network will always have at least one port open, even if it's open temporarily to receive return packets).
I would say A - first stage

B is nonsense bcs. you could also use tabular or vector variables.

I have to say B for one reason: If you query targets, you will get a specific variable that may only work for that target. With a Scalar variable, the variable will work for a wider variation of targets.

questions.question: For what is File Based Discovery used?
answers: A. To discover the checksum of a file and store it to track for changes
B. To discover the contents of flat files such as configuration files
C. To discover that file names conform to a defined naming standard
D. To discover file paths to recognize the signature of installed software

comments.content: A naming standard does not matter in discovery. However, the fastest way to find out the name of an application is to correlate its config file location to that of typical installations.

File-based Discovery probes execute a scan searching for specific file extensions or file names in paths that you configure. The resulting file information is returned in the probe payload. The sensor attempts to match the discovered files with installed software, using the file name, size, and version returned by the probe. File-based Discovery uses file signatures to detect software that might not have been registered.

Hardware Models can have a one-to-many relationship with the following:
(Choose three.)

comments.content:
ACE.
Option B is incorrect because a hardware model has a one-to-one relationship with the manufacturer, as a hardware model is typically associated with a single manufacturer.

A,C,E is correct. Manufacturer can have a one-to-many relationship with Models but not the other way around.

https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/xanadu-it-asset-management/page/product/product-catalog/concept/c_ModelCategories.html

A, C, E is correct.

If you look on the "cmdb_hardware_product_model" form, the manufacturer and owner fields is are reference fields and therefore can't have one-to-many relationships.

replies:
Change to B,D,E
confirmed in PDI again.

comments.content: A, C, E, confirmed on PDI

questions.question: What pattern operation allows the transfer of a file from the MID Server to a target?
On the ECC Queue, sensor records have a Queue value of ___________ and probe records have a Queue value of ___________.

comments.content:
A. Input, Output

Discovery Course - Module 5
To determine whether a record is for a probe or a sensor, look at the value in the Queue column. Sensor records are in the input queue, and probe records are in the output queue

i asked chatgpt-On the ECC Queue, sensor records have a Queue value of **`output`** and probe records have a Queue value of **`input`**.--Yes, I am confident. 

In **ServiceNow**, the **ECC (External Communication Channel) Queue** is used for communication between the ServiceNow instance and external systems or processes. The **`input`** queue is used for incoming messages (like probe results from MID Servers), and the **`output`** queue is used for outgoing messages (like sensor triggers sent to the MID Server). 

- **Sensor records** typically have a queue value of **`output`** because they represent commands or triggers sent to the MID Server for further processing.  
- **Probe records** have a queue value of **`input`** because they are results or responses sent back to the ServiceNow instance for processing. 

Let me know if you need further clarification!

replies:
A is the answer. The link you just shared shows this:

"Probes and sensors
Probes and sensors are scripts that collect and process data on a host and then update the CMDB. More specifically, probes explore or investigate CIs on your network, and sensors parse the data returned from the probes."

Probes are the output and sensors are the input.

questions.question: In Discovery, what table associates an IP address and a credential?
In general, Discovery can provide which of the following kinds of application relationships? (Choose two.)

comments.content:
B -AND- D
(the question asks you to choose two.)

Application to Application Relationships:
Application discovery identifies which applications are being used in a given environment. It allows organizations to understand the relationships between different applications. By mapping these relationships, IT teams gain insights into how applications interact with each other, their dependencies, and their respective workloads12.
Host to Application Relationships:
Application discovery also helps establish relationships between hosts (servers) and applications. It provides visibility into which applications are installed on specific hosts. Understanding these relationships is essential for managing and optimizing application performance, security, and resource allocation1.
Therefore, the correct answers are B. application to application and D. host to application.

questions.question: Which ECC Queue message contains the XML payload returned from the MID Server?
Which of the following executes the osquery commands on agents to gather attribute details from a CI?

comments.content:
This guide says it is D.
https://www.servicenow.com/community/itom-articles/build-your-own-acc-v-inventory-module-check-definition/ta-p/2368617

Once the Check Type is defines you need a check definition that define the way of querying the end-device.  This could be done with scripts, commands or with the build in OSQuery (https://osquery.io/). ACC-V uses OSQuery for other data detection, and is maintained by the Agent. 

The good thing is that there is a predefined Check Definition to run OSQuery (util.osquery.agent) that you can take inspiration from.
The Disco training has a slide which states: Check Definitions executes the osquery command on agents.  verbatim..  I'm suggesting D.

I wanted to make a correction. I found the answer in Module 7 of the lab. If you watch that module at the portion where it talks about Check Definitions, it says word for word "executes the osquery command on agents." and "osquery commands are used to gather specific attribute details..."
That being said the correct answer is actually D. Check Definitions
I also believe it is C
replies: The answer is D not C.

comments.content:
Could be C

Check site number 2 in the link
https://www.servicenow.com/content/dam/servicenow-assets/public/en-us/doc-type/resource-center/data-sheet/ds-itom-acc.pdf

ACC also supports
OSQuery, allowing you to query hosts and run remediation commands on

questions.question: What is the advantage of Discovery Range Sets?
answers: A. Range Sets are the only way to have more than one IP Range defined within a Discovery Schedule.
B. Range Sets show the number of IPs in a subnet.
C. All the necessary Range Sets are installed in the base installation of Discovery.
D. Range Sets provide flexibility in management and identification of known networks for simplicity of administration.

For Infrastructure
computer_system is the only Temporary Variable

For Application
computer_system & process this 2 are mandatory Temporary variable

questions.question: While discovering a new SNMP network device, which choice could cause the error “Active, couldn’t classify” to occur on a Discovery Status?
answers: A. A firewall blocking the communication between the MID Server and the target device.
C. SNMP only behavior is not configured.
D. An SNMP Classification must be updated or created for the new device.

comments.content:
The error message refers to a classification error.
If the SNMP credentials are incorrect (option B), the discovery attempt would fail completely when connecting to the device, but a classification error would not specifically occur.
From the self-paced learning troubleshooting module on Classification, it says that the classifier for SNMP is missing if you encounter this error
Based on the troubleshooting module of the self-paced training, the example they gave stated that this is the result of a classifier not existing for the specific CI.

I would say B based on this:
https://support.servicenow.com/kb?id=kb_article_view&sysparm_article=KB0535236

From this community thread D is correct, but documentation would be better to be completely sure.
https://www.servicenow.com/community/itom-forum/unable-to-discover-snmp-devices-active-could-t-classify/m-p/931929/page/3

questions.question: The deletion strategy is set to ‘Mark as absent’ for related Disk CIs discovered via the Linux Server pattern. If a related Disk CI is discovered during the Linux Server discovery and then the same related Disk CI is not found the next time the Linux Server is discovered, the following will happen:
answers: A. The Disk Status CI (install_status) is set to Absent.
B. The Disk CI Operational Status (operational_status) is set to Non-Operational.
C. The Linux Server CI Operational Status (operational_status) is set to Non-Operational.
D. The Linux Server CI Status (install_status) is set to Absent.

questions.question: Which of the choices best describes a tabular variable in a discovery pattern?
answers: C. Each cell is a CI attribute
D. Each cell is a scalar variable

comments.content:
D is correct 
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/vancouver-it-operations-management/page/product/service-mapping/reference/r_PatternVariables.html

A variable can be:
Scalar: A single string
Tabular: A table, where each cell is a scalar variable.
Vector: A single, unnamed column with as many rows as needed

questions.question: When configuring the MID Server Service Settings, which of the following is not a valid MID Server name?

comments.content:
C is correct
https://support.servicenow.com/kb?id=kb_article_view&sysparm_article=KB0744416

MID Server naming
The MID server name cannot start with "mid.server"

If it does, the the problem with inserting ECC records in the ECC queue fails to insert properly.

This is because the agent field in the ECC queue will append "mid.server" to the beginning of the MID server name. This causes the records in the ecc queue to be incorrect and fails to send commands to the MID server.

questions.question: Which one of the following is not used in a horizontal discovery pattern?

comments.content: I want to again correct my first answer. I think the correct answer is actually conectivity section. When you go to the pattern and select Infrastructure as the type, it shows two sections the "Identification section" and the "extension section". When you select application, it show both of those as well as a "Connection Section" not "Connectivity" I think this is a trick question.

B is correct. 
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/vancouver-it-operations-management/page/product/service-mapping/task/t_DefineConnecSectionPatDef.html

Procedure

Navigate to All > Pattern Designer > Discovery Patterns and open the required pattern from the pattern list.
The pattern must be of the Application type.

In the Connectivity Section, click New.
Note: The Connectivity Section is greyed out if the pattern cannot be edited for Service Mapping.

questions.question: How do you create relationships between CIs in a horizontal pattern?
answers: A. Relationships are created automatically for each successful connection section.
B. By using the Create Connections operation.
C. By using the Create Relation/Reference operation.
D. Relationships cannot be created via patterns.

comments.content:
As part of creating or modifying a discovery pattern, you can use the Relation and/or Reference condition to create relationships and references between CIs and their related items. This operation is relevant for both infrastructure and application patterns that Discovery uses for horizontal discovery.
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/washingtondc-it-operations-management/page/product/service-mapping/task/t_CreateARelationshipAndReference.html

questions.question: CI identifiers can be viewed under which of the following?
Which of the following best describes what may also be required when increasing the max number of threads for a MID Server?
answers: A. updating the acl rules for the CMDB tables in ServiceNow
B. increase the amount of disk space on the MID Server host
C. increasing the memory allocated to the MID Server app.
D. increase the MID Server max payload size

comments.content: C as otherwise you may get an out of memory error from the extra processing

To increase the number of threads, you might have to increase the amount of memory that Java uses. If you configure insufficient memory, an Out of memory error appears in the MID Server log.   I'm going with C

questions.question: Which part of Agent Client Collector must be configured to run osquery commands on a CI?

comments.content: kind of still both right.. a policy holds a check, the check itself executes the osquery, so i guess take the highest parent?

I selected Policies because the question asks "on a CI."
"Check" defines the queries or osquery commands that are executed.
"Policies" control when and on which CIs those queries are executed.
While the Check defines the specific queries, it is the Policy that triggers and executes them on the corresponding devices. In other words, Check Definitions do not execute on their own, and they must be associated with a Policy to be executed, and therefore I believe the correct answer is Policies.

C.
Example:
Check: A check is created to run the osquery command SELECT * FROM processes; to gather a list of running processes on the CI.
Policy: A policy is set up to run this check on all Windows servers every 24 hours.
Summary:
Checks specify the osquery commands to be run.
Policies determine when and on which CIs those checks are executed.
